_header: Toward the end of frosty January
Title(s): ‘Look in thy merour and deeme noon othir wiht’
Bibliographic Ghosts: San Marino, CA, Henry Huntington Library HM 140 [olim Phillipps 8299]: miswritten for 5966, which is in this MS.
_description: John Lydgate, ‘Look in thy merour and deeme noon othir wiht’ — twenty-seven 8-line stanzas (ababbcbc) with this refrain, including Envoy

BodArcSelB10.First Lines:
Loke in thy myrroure and deme non other wyghtThe kynge of soules
                    moste imperyall…
BodArcSelB10.Last Lines:
…Mercy to medle wyth trouthe and equyteAnd loke well theyre
                    myrours & deme non other wyght
BodArcSelB10.Note: 25 stanzas and one line; missing stanzas 1-2.

BodRawC86.First Lines:
Towarde thende of ffrosty Ianu IanuaryWhan vatery phebus
                    had his purpas take…
BodRawC86.Last Lines:
…Mercy to medel trovth and equyteLoke wele ye myrrours &
                    deme neuer oþer wyght
BodRawC86.Attributed Author:
Iohn Lidgate (added by hand of the sixteenth century to top margin f.
                        81v); Lidgate (added by a fifteenth- to sixteenth century-hand to
                    top left margin, f. 81v)

CamJes56.First Lines:
[T]Owarde the eende of frosty IanuarieWhan watery Phebus had his
                    purpos take…
CamJes56.Last Lines:
…Mercye to medle with trouth and equiteeLooke wele youre
                    myrrours and deme noon other wight

BLHar2255.First Lines:
TOward the Ende of ffroosty IanuaryeWhan watry Phebus had his
                    purpoos take…
BLHar2255.Last Lines:
…Mercy to medle with trouthe and equyteLook weel your myrours
                    and deeme noon othir wiht Explict
